abstract: Using creative videos, Old Spice aggressively markets to women shower gel made for men. But will real men abandon bar soap for body wash?
snippet: Using creative videos, Old Spice aggressively markets to women shower gel made for men. But will real men abandon bar soap for body wash?
lead_paragraph: WHEN Old Spice, the 72-year-old Procter & Gamble brand, was planning a new advertising campaign for shower gel earlier this year, it faced a challenge: its research suggested women purchase as much as 70 percent of the shower gel for men in their households, but using body wash struck some men as unmanly. How could they market body wash to female purchasers and yet still cast the product as decidedly masculine to lure men away from bar soap?

headline.main: Old Spice Argues That Real Men Smell Good
headline.print_headline: Old Spice Argues That Real Men Smell Good
